description: David's review sounds more like a review of his technical skills rather than this product.

Seeing some pretty negative reviews here which I think is undeserved. Sure it's pretty basic but that's what this application is; A basic interface for manipulating lower level stuff such as Gnome's Keyring. And it does that pretty okay in a stable way. However people seem to think they are entitled to more and start slapping one star reviews on it.

There' supposed to be someway to create an ascii exported public key, for example, (above "export" in the drop down menu except it isn't there and none of the export files can be read by standard txt editors. They just have .pgp extension on them.
summary: Yeah, it actually created a test key!

description: Everyone seems to think this is a password manager. If you compare it to LastPass, Dashlane, or 1Password, sure, it's horrible, but that's not what it is. It's an interface for managing your Gnome Keyring, and for that, it's great. When rating the app, please remember that this does not store your passwords, it allows you to see and manage the passwords that something else has stored.
I don't understand the poor reviews. I believe interfaces such as this do not require their own security. This product is exactly what I require.
summary: Great for managing keys, if your system is secure

description: I don't get the negative comments. Sounds like stereotypical "power users" complaining that it doesn't do everything you can do on cli. I think they're missing the point.
summary: Great for simple actions related to gpg

description: It's doesn't do what I was expecting to do.
weak software, which asks for a password, there is no option to enter it permanently, it is a problem for people with problems, your own security
Excellent tool for tracking and storing both yout crypto keys and those that you trust. Excellent password and security certificate vault.
This app has quite a few bugs, mostly around date handling. Makes it very hard to use.
This is not a password word manager, those giving bad reviews seem to think it is.
summary: Does what it's designed to do

description: the description and the GUI confuse users as to what it's purpose and mode of operation is. it might be designed for a mobile/desktop hybrid use but come-on !
I don't think there's anything behind the high CPU usage. It's gotta be a bug. For 15 minutes, it's been at the top. Fan is running high. Disk and memory usage hasn't changed.

description: Simply does not work

There's a few disgruntled users here; we have lost our way.

Gnome, oh Gnome,
You are not my home.
You are used by many,
A place where Geeks can call home.

Your forefathers were simple,
And pioneered great feats,
But now you resource intensive,
And we are spoiled with treats.

Your RAM requirements are a mile long,
And my CPU usage is mile high.
If I am to use you, 
How will I get by?

For you see Linux was meant to be simple.
Do one thing, and do it well,
But now it is a pimple
And I must apply anti-fungal gel.
summary: Simple software following the UNIX philosophy

description: Just wanted to echo what most already have here. It technically works. But it's a little obtuse to use and gives no user feedback other than when a keyring needs to be unlocked. It saved a network SMB password but doesn't seem to have a way to create one from scratch!?
I install via snap and it's a no show?? Never did show up so I can't try it.
It just works as expected for me. Thank you.

These passwords can be seen by pasting into gedit! I like the idea of storing passwords as nowadays there are so many. Each site now has different criteria for passwords and it's always more secure using different passwords for each site. This app needs a user login and a master password recoverable by sending a special password to a predefined email address (generated by using logged in username combined with certain system properties, computer name or serial number from bios, anything to keep from a master pw or another user (of the same system) from getting into stored passwords). Also needs a web address to enter to take you directly to the website that the password is for.

Cant import my gpg nor my ssh key (both encrypted) in either the flatpak or the rpm version, when trying to add the gpg key it doesnt even ask for the password and just fails and when trying to add the ssh key I unlock it but then the import key is greyed out. Would have been cool to have a graphical key manager but no luck I guess
